summary:
The Security Council, 
Welcoming the report of the Secretary-General on the United Nations operation in Cyprus, 
Noting the need to extend the mandate of the UN Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP) beyond 31 January 2017, 
Noting the Secretary-General's intention to report on his Good Offices, 
Reaffirming the primary role of the UN in assisting the parties to achieve a comprehensive and durable settlement, 
Welcoming progress in negotiations between Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders, 
Recalling the importance of negotiations resulting in a bicommunal, bizonal federation with political equality, 
Encouraging intensification of substantive negotiations on core issues, 
Stressing the unsustainability of the status quo, 
Noting the need for military confidence-building measures, 
Reaffirming the importance of Green Line crossings, 
Convinced of the benefits of a comprehensive settlement, 
Urging leaders to foster positive public rhetoric and explain settlement benefits, 
Highlighting the supporting role of the international community, 
Taking note of the stable security situation, 
Recalling the Secretary-General's belief that the buffer zone situation would improve if both sides accepted the 1989 aide-memoire, 
Noting with regret the withholding of access to minefields, 
Commending the Committee on Missing Persons, 
Agreeing on the essential role of civil society groups in the political process.
Here is a summarized version of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:

Stresses the need for a rigorous approach to peacekeeping deployments and welcomes the Secretary-General's intention to review UNFICYP's efficiency and effectiveness.

Appreciates the efforts of Special Representative Elizabeth Spehar, Special Adviser Espen Barth Eide, and Force Commander Major General Mohammad Humayun Kabir.

Welcomes progress in leaders-led negotiations and encourages the sides to reach a comprehensive and durable settlement.

Takes note of the Secretary-General's report (S/2017/20) and recalls Security Council resolution 2263 (2016).

Calls upon the two leaders to:

* Work on reaching convergences on core issues
* Continue working with Technical Committees to improve daily lives of Cypriots
* Improve the public atmosphere for negotiations
* Increase civil society participation

Requests the Secretary-General to intensify transition planning and encourages the sides to engage with UNFICYP and the United Nations Good Offices mission.

Urges implementation of confidence-building measures, including military measures and opening of crossing points.

Welcomes efforts to accommodate the Committee on Missing Persons and calls for full access to all areas.

Reaffirms relevant resolutions on Cyprus, particularly resolution 1251 (1999).

Expresses full support for UNFICYP and extends its mandate until 31 July 2017.

Calls on both sides to:

* Engage in consultations with UNFICYP on buffer zone demarcation and the 1989 aide-memoire
* Restore the military status quo in Strovilia
* Allow access to deminers and facilitate mine removal

Requests the Secretary-General to report on implementation by 10 July 2017.

Welcomes UNFICYP's efforts to implement the Secretary-General's zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse.

Decides to remain seized of the matter.
